thread.title: US stocks drop ahead of Fed meeting, Apple results
thread.title_full: US stocks drop ahead of Fed meeting, Apple results

title: US stocks drop ahead of Fed meeting, Apple results
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 26, 2015, 14:54 GMT - UK Markets close in 1 hr 36 mins US stocks drop ahead of Fed meeting, Apple results AFP â€“ 18 minutes ago View Photo 

US stocks fell early Wednesday, giving back some of last week's big gains ahead of major earnings reports and a Federal Reserve policy meeting later this week. 
About 45 minutes into trade, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was at 17,615.90, down 30.80 points (0.17 percent). 
The broad-based S&P 500 shed 7.91 (0.38 percent) to 2,067.24, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 18.56 (0.37 percent) to 5,013.30 
Earnings from ExxonMobil and Chevron (Swiss: CVX.SW - news ) are expected to show the damage from lower oil prices, while Apple (LSE: 0R2V.L - news ) will look to keep up the momentum for the tech sector following strong results last week from Microsoft (NasdaqGS: MSFT - news ) and others. 
Apple dropped 2.9 percent, while ExxonMobil and Chevron lost 1.2 percent and 2.2 percent, respectively. 
The Fed's two-day policy meeting is expected to again put off raising interest rates, but it could make clearer how soon a rate hike could come. 
US stocks have risen the last four weeks, pushing the S&P 500 back into positive territory for 2015. 
Piedmont Natural Gas, which distributes natural gas in three southern states in the US, jumped 37.3 percent on news it will be acquired by Duke Energy $4.9 billion. Duke dropped 2.1 percent. 
Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (NYSE: VRX - news ) fell 5.1 percent as it sought to tamp down questions about its accounting and financial dealings. 
The drugmaker announced an ad-hoc committee to review allegations over its business relationship with Philidor, a specialty pharma company. In a conference call with financial analysts, Valeant executives defended the company from allegations its accounting treatment of Philidor is an effort to disguise fraud. 
Chinese Internet search company Baidu (Xetra: A0F5DE - news ) jumped 7.1 percent after announcing a share exchange transaction involving a pair Chinese travel companies, Ctrip.com International and Qunar Cayman Islands. Ctrip and Qunar Cayman, which also trade in the US, jumped 23.8 percent and 15.1 percent. 
Bond prices rose. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury fell to 2.06 percent from 2.08 percent Friday, while the 30-year dipped to 2.87 percent from 2.90 percent. Bond prices and yields move inversely.
